Posts.Content: Dorothy89 wrote: I have found this board to be such a place of solace, hope and information. I have more questions and am hopeful that you all can help once again. I had a lumpectomy on 5/30 w/ sentinal node biopsy. The tumor was 2.3 cm, stage IIA cancer. They took 3 nodes, no sign of cancer there. I see my surgeon tomorrow morning for follow up and an onocologist on Tuesday morning. Any ideas on questions for them would be appreciated. I have read a lot of statistics on these boards re treatments and recurrance statistics. I would like to find some statistics on survival w/ w/out additional treatment after surgery. If anybody has any websites please send them to me. If the cancer is not in my nodes, what do you think about not doing rad and chemo and perhaps working on building up my immune system instead? Thank you for your thoughts. Peace, Dorothy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Treatment decisions Dorothy89 2verna2

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2007 07:24AM Dorothy89 wrote: Thank you, I forgot to add that I am 57, post menopausal and the tumor was a grade 3 - very aggressive.

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2007 07:14AM Dorothy89 wrote: wow, thank you for all the info I need to find out from the dr. The only question I could answer at this point, is that the dr told me over the phone that the ER/Pr was 97% positive. What exactly does that mean? I feel so ignorant, I have tried to read info, but feel like my brain is a sieve.
Posts.Title: Treatment decisions Dorothy89 2verna2

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2007 09:05AM Dorothy89 wrote: Thank you all so much. The medical staff was wonderful, they put the cream on me as soon as I got to the hospital and the dye injection was just a sting. The radiologists was generous with lidocaine and although the experience was very stressful, I can't say enough good things about the kindness of that medical community. And it looks like the cancer was contained to my breast and not lymph nodes. Thank you all for being here for me. It has meant the world. Peace, Dorothy

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2007 03:49PM Dorothy89 wrote: I also had lumps from nursing and it is always good to get breast lumps checked, you will sleep easier. I couldn't wear any kind of underwire or tight bra while nursing, or I would have lumps and plugged ducts. So glad you are getting insurance and seeing the dr just to be safe. Sending good wishes, Dorothy

Posts.Title: stereotactic biopsy Dorothy89 fran93420

Posts.Content: May 20, 2007 06:12PM Dorothy89 wrote: The medication just helps to not obsess about what might be and to stay focused on the activity we are engaged in the moment. Of course cancer and chemo are not death sentences, it is only our fear that tells us they are. The medication helps to keep those fears unders some control and to focus on a more positive future and outcome. I hope that you can see the dr to get meds and then after you get some meds go sooner to the dr re your lump. That will ultimately help to reduce anxiety of the unknown, doing nothing is ever so much scarier than doing something. Peace
